clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Study of the Neuro-Spinal Scaffold for the Treatment of AIS A Cervical Acute SCI
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study of Clinical Safety and Feasibility of the Neuro-Spinal Scaffold for the Treatment of Complete (AIS A) Traumatic Acute Spinal Cord Injury at the C5 - T1 Neurological Levels

brief_summary.textblock: Pilot Study of Clinical Safety and Feasibility of the Neuro-Spinal ScaffoldTM for the Treatment of Complete (AIS A) Traumatic Acute Spinal Cord Injury at the C5-T1 Neurological Levels The purpose of this study is to support an expansion to support marketing applications as well as future studies.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study did not enroll any subjects.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of all Adverse Device Effects of any kind/seriousness.

other_outcome.measure: American Spinal Injury Association Impairment Scale (AIS) improvement of one or more grade
other_outcome.description: International Standards for Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury (ISNCSCI) Exams

other_outcome.measure: Improvements in motor and sensory scores
Improvements in Graded Redefined Assessment of Strength, Sensibility and Prehension (GRASSP)

clinical_study.condition: Traumatic Cervical Acute Spinal Cord Injury

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 16-70 years of age, inclusive
- AIS A classification of traumatic spinal cord injury with a neurological level within C5-T1 inclusive
- Recent injury
- Non-penetrating SCI
Exclusion Criteria:
- Terminally ill subjects not likely to be able to participate in follow-up
- Incomplete spinal cord injury (AIS B, C, D, and E injuries)
- No identifiable intra-spinal cavity following myelotomy/irrigation in the contused spinal cord in which a Scaffold can be placed
- Spinal cord injury associated with significant traumatic brain injury or coma that
- Radiographic or visual evidence of parenchymal dissociation or anatomic transection as determined by the Investigator where the contusion completely bridges a full cross-section of the spinal cord
- Subjects with spinal cord injuries directly due to gunshot, knife, or other penetrating wounds
